Award.AwardTitle: High density capacitors: bridging the performance gap between conventional capacitors and electric double layer capacitors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The low capacitance density of electrolytic capacitors is becoming a limiting factor on circuit board profile and circuit performance. The capacitance density of the current generation of electric double layer supercapacitors is several orders of magnitude higher, but they are limited to a charge-discharge rate of about 1 second, or a characteristic frequency of 1 hertz, and thus not suitable for those circuit applications requiring capacitors that must run in the hundreds of hertz to kilohertz range. In other words, there exists a significant performance gap, in terms of capacitance/frequency, between currently available supercapacitor and traditional circuit capacitor technologies. The proposed research addresses this performance gap through studies aimed at developing ultrafast supercapacitors with novel nanostructured electrodes and a high capacitance density that run in the hundreds of hertz to kilohertz range and are suitable for circuit applications. This research, if successful, will bring about disruptive change in capacitor design and ground-breaking applications in crucial circuit functions like decoupling, timing, filtering, and power supply and conditioning. The proposed nanostructured electrodes can additionally be utilized in battery and electrocatalyst applications. Education and outreach activities are integrated in this project for the training of undergraduate and graduate students. In addition to supported Research Experiences for Undergraduates program students, several undergraduate students will be involved in the project through their Project Lab course work, to inspire their interest in advanced studies. Attention will be paid to recruiting female and minority students, particularly first-generation college students, to secure diversity and broad participation. An outreach component on nanomaterials for energy technologies will be developed to educate students who will serve as ambassadors in subsequent outreach efforts coordinated by the T-STEM Center of Texas Tech University.

The proposed research will characterize and demonstrate high-density capacitors running in the hundreds of hertz to kilohertz frequency range. This represents a disruptive advance in capacitor technology for compact and efficient ultrafast electric double layer capacitors as discrete components, for line-frequency alternating current filtering, and on-chip integrated high-density micro-capacitor needs. The proposed electrode is based on perpendicularly edge-oriented multilayer graphene grown on a cellulose nanofiber scaffold. This novel material has a shallow, straight forward, wide-open pore structure that ensures high frequency response while its large specific surface area and especially high density of fully exposed graphene edges offer the possibility of large capacitance. Edge-oriented multilayer graphene growth and cellulose fiber carbonization into carbon nanofiber are implemented in a process that requires only a few minutes' time. The ultrafast electric double layer capacitors based on this new material could allow at least two orders of volume reduction compared to low-voltage aluminum electrolytic capacitors for filtering. The resulting freestanding electrodes can also be transferred to a substrate or an integrated circuit chip for in-package or on-chip capacitor integration. This project comprises comprehensive nanomaterial and charge storage studies, device modeling, fabrication and performance testing. If successful, it will ultimately bridge the frequency/capacitance gap between existing circuit capacitors and supercapacitors. The outcomes of this study will in addition enhance understanding in the areas of related materials and devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With integrated semiconductor chips become smaller and more powerful, capacitors, one of the essential components in any circuit design, are becoming a factor limiting circuit board profile and performance. This is particularly true when large capacitance, from micro-faraday (?F) to mil-faraday (mF) or even high is needed, and the only option is the low performance aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs), but it has a large internal resistance (equivalent series resistance, ESR) and a bulky size. New capacitor technologies that can substitute AECs are in desperate needs.

With a high-density capacitor technology, circuit profiles can be dramatically reduced and offer much improved performance. This project is to investigate and develop high-frequency electrochemical capacitors (HF-ECs) to meet this need. The currently available electrochemical capacitors, or supercapacitors, although have a capacitance density several orders of magnitude larger than AECs, but can only run up to a characteristic frequency of 1 hertz (Hz), above which, they behaves more like a resistor, not a capacitor.  They are not suitable for circuit applications which require capacitors running at least hundreds or kilo hertz range. Therefore, a significant performance gap, in terms of capacitance/frequency, exist between the currently available supercapacitor technology and the traditional circuit capacitor technologies. This project is to address this fundamental performance gap by studying and developing HF-ECs that have large capacitance density while running at kilo Hz or even high frequency range, suitable for circuit applications.

To meet the demanding requirements of both high capacitance density and high response frequency, the project was focused on designing and investigating several nanostructures that provide both high specific surface area for high capacitance density and high electric conductivity for high frequency response. Electrolyte, both aqueous and organic based, were also studied since it is another key component in determining the frequency response. In addition to gain fundament understanding on nanostructured electrodes and their electrochemical capacitive characteristics, in this project, HF-ECs, as proof of concept devices, were fabricated to characterize their fundamental performance and to confirm their large capacitance and capacitive behavior up to hundreds of kilo hertz of frequencies, and their applications in circuits were also demonstrated, suggesting our HF-EC technology very promising as a new generation capacitor technology for circuit miniaturization.

      In the following, we list a few key outcomes of this project.

  • By fabricating intrinsically interconnected carbon nanofiber-based carbon nanoweb structure, which was converted from biopolymer nanofibers with a diameter 20-50 nm through our rapid plasma carbonization process to control the porous structure, we achieved high-performance HF-ECs in terms of capacitance density, characteristic frequency, and phase angle at 120 Hz.
  • By studying vertical graphene deposition in carbonized metal organic structure (MOF) in a less than 10 minutes rapid process, we demonstrated HF-ECs exhibiting very low equivalent ESR of 40 ​mΩ ​cm−2 and attractive cell capacitance of 1.02 ​mF ​cm−2 and phase angle of −85.9? or 2.34 ​mF ​cm−2 and -80.6? at 120 ​Hz, which are the best reported overall performances thus far.
  • The proof-of-concept HF-EC devices were incorporated into circuits to demonstrate their alternative current (AC) filtering capability and pulse power (energy) storage capability, suggesting the potential of these HF-ECs in substitution of AECs in practical circuits.
  • Four Ph.D students (including one female) and one Master student were trained in this project. Four undergraduate students, including female and minority, were also involved in the study.
  • Eleven papers were published and multiple conference or invited presentations were made to disseminate the findings of this research.
  • A U.S. patent application ?High Frequency Supercapacitors and Methods of Making Same? was filed and was very recently allowed.
  • The technology developed in this project was licensed to a small business for commercialization.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2020
Modified by: Zhaoyang Fan

Image
  • HF-ECs have a much smaller size, lower loss, and other merits comparing to the current aluminum electrolytic capacitors and will significantly downscale the circuit profile.
    Zhaoyang Fan

    Zhaoyang Fan
    HF-EC technology
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: With integrated semiconductor chips become smaller and more powerful, capacitors, one of the essential components in any circuit design, are becoming a factor limiting circuit board profile and performance. This is particularly true when large capacitance, from micro-faraday (?F) to mil-faraday (mF) or even high is needed, and the only option is the low performance aluminum electrolytic capacitors (AECs), but it has a large internal resistance (equivalent series resistance, ESR) and a bulky size. New capacitor technologies that can substitute AECs are in desperate needs. With a high-density capacitor technology, circuit profiles can be dramatically reduced and offer much improved performance. This project is to investigate and develop high-frequency electrochemical capacitors (HF-ECs) to meet this need. The currently available electrochemical capacitors, or supercapacitors, although have a capacitance density several orders of magnitude larger than AECs, but can only run up to a characteristic frequency of 1 hertz (Hz), above which, they behaves more like a resistor, not a capacitor. They are not suitable for circuit applications which require capacitors running at least hundreds or kilo hertz range. Therefore, a significant performance gap, in terms of capacitance/frequency, exist between the currently available supercapacitor technology and the traditional circuit capacitor technologies. This project is to address this fundamental performance gap by studying and developing HF-ECs that have large capacitance density while running at kilo Hz or even high frequency range, suitable for circuit applications. To meet the demanding requirements of both high capacitance density and high response frequency, the project was focused on designing and investigating several nanostructures that provide both high specific surface area for high capacitance density and high electric conductivity for high frequency response. Electrolyte, both aqueous and organic based, were also studied since it is another key component in determining the frequency response. In addition to gain fundament understanding on nanostructured electrodes and their electrochemical capacitive characteristics, in this project, HF-ECs, as proof of concept devices, were fabricated to characterize their fundamental performance and to confirm their large capacitance and capacitive behavior up to hundreds of kilo hertz of frequencies, and their applications in circuits were also demonstrated, suggesting our HF-EC technology very promising as a new generation capacitor technology for circuit miniaturization. In the following, we list a few key outcomes of this project. By fabricating intrinsically interconnected carbon nanofiber-based carbon nanoweb structure, which was converted from biopolymer nanofibers with a diameter 20-50 nm through our rapid plasma carbonization process to control the porous structure, we achieved high-performance HF-ECs in terms of capacitance density, characteristic frequency, and phase angle at 120 Hz. By studying vertical graphene deposition in carbonized metal organic structure (MOF) in a less than 10 minutes rapid process, we demonstrated HF-ECs exhibiting very low equivalent ESR of 40 ​mΩ ​cm−2 and attractive cell capacitance of 1.02 ​mF ​cm−2 and phase angle of −85.9? or 2.34 ​mF ​cm−2 and -80.6? at 120 ​Hz, which are the best reported overall performances thus far. The proof-of-concept HF-EC devices were incorporated into circuits to demonstrate their alternative current (AC) filtering capability and pulse power (energy) storage capability, suggesting the potential of these HF-ECs in substitution of AECs in practical circuits. Four Ph.D students (including one female) and one Master student were trained in this project. Four undergraduate students, including female and minority, were also involved in the study. Eleven papers were published and multiple conference or invited presentations were made to disseminate the findings of this research. A U.S. patent application ?High Frequency Supercapacitors and Methods of Making Same? was filed and was very recently allowed. The technology developed in this project was licensed to a small business for commercialization. Last Modified: 10/10/2020 Submitted by: Zhaoyang Fan
